Award.AwardTitle: CRII: III: Automated Discovery of Predictive Regulatory Models from Morphogenetic Experimental Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Continuous advances in molecular biology are producing an extraordinary amount of detail about the necessary genes required for multicellular organisms to grow the correct shapes and forms during development and regeneration. However, reconstructing the genetic mechanisms explaining precisely the experimentally observed patterns and, more importantly, the morphological outcomes in terms of shape and forms, is an extraordinarily difficult task for human scientists due to the complex regulatory networks and dynamics characteristic of biological processes. This project will produce and use novel computational tools to aid in the discovery of dynamic predictive models explaining at once the exponentially growing experimental datasets of morphogenetic shapes, forms, and patterns. The interdisciplinary characteristic of this project will foster new links between computational and biological sciences, resulting in fundamental changes in the research methodology in these fields that will lead to an acceleration of novel applications in developmental and regenerative medicine. The computational tools developed in this work will also serve as educational advances for the teaching of dynamic regulation and systems theory in biology, computer science, engineering, and mathematics. Importantly, this project will involve graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. This work will be performed at UMBC, which has traditionally served large minority communities, and this project will advance the participation of these communities in the fast-paced field of computational biology.

This research will develop the necessary set of computational algorithms and tools that will readily assist scientists in the discovery of the genetic mechanisms controlling the development of biological shapes, forms, and patterns. The technical methods to be employed will include: the use of a mathematical ontology for experimental perturbations, genetic expression patterns, and morphological outcomes; a computationally-efficient continuous modeling approach based on partial differential equations for both genetic regulation and biomechanical forces; and high-performance heuristic methods for the automation of the discovery of regulatory models. The project will be grounded on mathematical models of partial differential equations, which will leverage our understanding of biological mechanisms of morphogenesis using the theory of dynamical systems. Furthermore, these novel computational tools will allow us to streamline the building of predictive, dynamic models of morphogenesis, explain the ever-increasing large dataset of morphogenetic experiments being laboriously produced by the community, and advance many fields of biology and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has produced novel computational methods, software tools, and databases with user-friendly interfaces for the understanding of the regulatory mechanisms controlling complex tissue patterning. Building predictive models based on rigorous biophysical mechanisms is essential for the understanding of the regulation of morphological outcomes during development. However, creating these models is a current challenge despite the large amount of experiments being currently produced in the literature due to both the inherent complexity, nonlinearities, and feedback loops of gene regulatory networks and the difficulty to model the biophysical dynamics of tissue patterning. Furthermore, these experimental datasets are mainly disseminated with textual descriptions and microscopy images published in manuscripts dispersed the literature, which are hard to analyze. Hence, extracting mechanistic knowledge from experimental datasets of morphologies and gene patterns is a current bottleneck in need of novel computational approaches. To overcome these challenges, this project has developed (1) a new computational framework for the biophysical simulation of tissue patterning, (2) new formalization methods based on mathematical descriptions and ontological annotations that are able to unambiguously describe complex spatial morphological data, (3) a new database of morphological and gene expression patterns images with a user-friendly freely-available web interface, and (4) a machine learning methodology for the discovery of regulatory models controlling morphological tissue patterns. 

We have demonstrated these novel methods with a freely-available curating software tool and comprehensive database of annotated planarian morphologies and their gene expression patterns, including a web tool with a user-friendly interface for access and query by any user. Furthermore, these centralized datasets are not only helpful for human scientists, but they are also amenable for sophisticated computational analysis. For this, the project has developed a novel machine learning methodology to discover gene regulatory networks controlling the development of specific tissue patterns. Given a set of gene expression patterns, the algorithm can automatically infer gene regulatory networks responsible for the development of these observed patterns. These gene networks represent a mechanistic explanation of the experimental phenotypes given as input. Using these novel computational tools and methods, the project has produced new insights into the regulatory mechanisms controlling complex global tissue behaviors during development and regeneration. The computational framework for biophysical simulation was used to explain sorting, intercalation, and involution cellular dynamics essential for embryonic development. In addition, the project discovered a new model of the genetic regulation for whole-organism regeneration and fission behaviors in planaria. In summary, the project has produced a set of new computational methods, tools, and resources for the extraction of mechanistic knowledge from experimental datasets towards the understanding of the genetic mechanisms controlling the development and regeneration of biological tissue patterns.

The project Broader Impacts included advancements in the synergy between computational and biological sciences, in new resources for the scientific and educational communities, and in the training of graduate and undergraduate students, including underrepresented groups in STEM fields, at the interface of computing and biology. This project served as a bridge between core computer science disciplines, including machine learning, simulation, and high performance computing, and core biology disciplines, such as developmental, regenerative, and genetics biology.  The synergy created between these fields made possible to solve new problems that could not have been accomplished with independent isolated approaches. This project put special emphasis in developing user-friendly interfaces for the freely-available resources created. This has benefitted not only the scientific community at large, but they also serve as valuable educational tools in the classroom, in addition to popularize the contributions of computer science to a broader audience. This project trained two graduate students and ten undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups in computational sciences and STEM fields and women, increasing the diversity in these areas. These students were trained with hands-on experiences at the interface of computational and biological sciences, which will have a long-term benefit to society for advancing scientific discoveries and engineering applications towards new biomedical solutions in the areas of birth defects, cancer formation, and regenerative medicine.
